exampleSentence: The prosaic lecture failed to engage the audience.
New evidence bolstered his argument.

definition: done routinely and with little interest or care
exampleSentence: She gave a perfunctory nod before leaving.

definition: reluctant to draw attention to yourself
exampleSentence: He remained reticent about his past achievements.
No one could gainsay the evidence presented.
The garrulous neighbor talked for hours about nothing.
The erudite professor impressed everyone with her insights.
The scandal precipitated his resignation.

definition: temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
exampleSentence: Her gregarious personality made her popular at parties.
His diffidence prevented him from speaking up.
Politicians often prevaricate when asked direct questions.

definition: naive and easily deceived or tricked
exampleSentence: The gullible customer fell for the scam.
Her laudable efforts improved the community.

definition: a person who speaks more than one language
exampleSentence: The polyglot translator spoke seven languages fluently.

definition: charge falsely or with malicious intent
exampleSentence: Critics tried to denigrate his achievements.

definition: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
exampleSentence: The obsequious assistant agreed with everything the boss said.

definition: make impure by adding a foreign or inferior substance
exampleSentence: The company was fined for adulterating their products.
She took a pragmatic approach to solving the problem.
His implacable enemy refused any peace offerings.

definition: intended to attract notice and impress others
exampleSentence: The ostentatious display of wealth drew criticism.

definition: the use of tricks to deceive someone
exampleSentence: He achieved success through guile rather than talent.

definition: provide physical relief, as from pain
exampleSentence: Nothing could assuage her grief.
His laconic responses revealed little about his thoughts.
The tropical heat enervated the travelers.

definition: a person who is devoted to eating and drinking to excess
exampleSentence: The gourmand sampled every dish at the buffet.

definition: someone who dislikes people in general
exampleSentence: The misanthrope preferred the company of books to people.
Social media platforms have proliferated in recent years.
Winning the championship filled them with euphoria.
She vacillated between the two job offers.
They tried to goad him into making a mistake.
The hot weather made everyone feel lethargic.

definition: of or relating to voluntary action for the public good
exampleSentence: Her philanthropic donations helped many charities.

definition: all of the same or similar kind or nature
exampleSentence: The homogeneous mixture had uniform properties.
The sun desiccated the exposed soil.
Fame can be ephemeral in the entertainment industry.
The policy engendered widespread controversy.

definition: a person who pleads for a person, cause, or idea
exampleSentence: She became an advocate for environmental protection.

definition: disposed to venture or take risks
exampleSentence: The audacious plan surprised everyone.
The time travel story created an interesting paradox.

definition: capable of being shaped or bent or drawn out
exampleSentence: Gold is highly malleable and can be shaped easily.
There was clear antipathy between the rival teams.

definition: using or containing too many words
exampleSentence: His verbose writing style made the report tedious.

definition: liable to lead to sudden change or violence
exampleSentence: The volatile market kept investors on edge.
The new measures helped mitigate the risks.

definition: a person who pays more attention to formal rules and book learning than they merit
exampleSentence: The pedant corrected every minor grammatical error.

definition: something that baffles understanding and cannot be explained
exampleSentence: Her disappearance remains an enigma to this day.
She pursued her goals with remarkable zeal.

definition: an absence of emotion or enthusiasm
exampleSentence: Voter apathy led to low turnout.
The placid lake reflected the mountains perfectly.
Witnesses corroborated her account of events.
They hosted a lavish celebration.
She always maintained strict propriety in public.

definition: try to gain favor by cringing or flattering
exampleSentence: Employees who fawn over the boss are rarely respected.

definition: regard with feelings of respect and reverence
exampleSentence: Many cultures venerate their ancestors.
The cacophony of car horns filled the street.

definition: treat or speak of with contempt
exampleSentence: Critics derided the film as pretentious.
Her ingenuous questions revealed her inexperience.

definition: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
exampleSentence: The iconoclast challenged traditional artistic norms.
The dissonance in modern music can be jarring.

definition: be deliberately ambiguous or unclear in order to mislead
exampleSentence: The witness seemed to equivocate under questioning.
The obdurate child refused to apologize.

definition: deviating from the general or common order or type
exampleSentence: The anomalous data point skewed the results.
Critics lauded her performance as groundbreaking.

definition: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
exampleSentence: The capricious weather made planning difficult.
His erudition was evident in every lecture.

definition: become less in amount or intensity
exampleSentence: The storm showed no signs of abating.

definition: run away, usually includes taking something along
exampleSentence: The treasurer absconded with the company funds.
Her eloquent speech moved the audience to tears.
The loquacious guest dominated every conversation.

definition: feeling regret for a fault or offence
exampleSentence: He appeared genuinely contrite after the incident.
The evidence seemed to inculpate the suspect.
The paucity of resources hampered the project.

definition: something that is inappropriate for the given time period
exampleSentence: The telephone in the medieval film was an anachronism.

definition: unsure how to act or respond
exampleSentence: She was nonplussed by the unexpected question.
His artless manner charmed everyone he met.
The empire sought hegemony over the region.
His prolix explanations tested everyone's patience.

definition: an expert in a specific field
exampleSentence: Political pundits debated the election results.
The puzzle confounded even the experts.

definition: the quality of being economical with money or food
exampleSentence: Her frugality allowed her to save for retirement.

definition: a long, strongly expressed speech or lecture
exampleSentence: The manager's harangue lasted nearly an hour.

definition: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
exampleSentence: The film was full of banal dialogue.
The veracious account matched all known facts.

definition: markedly different from an accepted norm
exampleSentence: His aberrant behavior concerned his colleagues.

definition: found in the ordinary course of events
exampleSentence: She longed to escape her mundane routine.

definition: unwilling to spend money or use resources
exampleSentence: The parsimonious landlord refused all repairs.
His pusillanimous response disappointed his supporters.
Her ebullient personality brightened the room.

definition: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges
exampleSentence: New evidence exculpated the wrongly accused man.

definition: the quality of being wordy and talkative
exampleSentence: His garrulity made meetings run overtime.

definition: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
exampleSentence: The impertinent remark offended the host.
His mendacity eventually destroyed his reputation.

definition: the fact of prevaricating or lying
exampleSentence: The witness's prevarication was obvious to all.

definition: making a show of being morally superior to other people
exampleSentence: His sanctimonious attitude alienated his friends.
The solicitous nurse checked on patients frequently.
The proposal received universal approbation.
The insipid meal disappointed the food critic.
The monk led an ascetic lifestyle.
The divorce was marked by considerable acrimony.
She sued the newspaper for publishing calumny.

definition: subject to sudden or unpredictable changes of mood or mind
exampleSentence: His mercurial temperament made him difficult to work with.

definition: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
exampleSentence: The argument was based on fallacious assumptions.
